Award.AwardTitle: Scholarship for Service in Information Assurance program at The Pennsylvania State University

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The College of Information Science and Technology (IST) at Penn State is supporting three cohorts of undergraduate and graduate students in Security and Risk Analysis and related programs via a Federal Cyber Service: Scholarship for Service (SFS) in Information Assurance program.

SFS students are enrolling in a strong interdisciplinary program in cybersecurity offered by the College of IST and are preparing to identify and solve security and privacy problems from technical, legal, ethical, policy, and business perspectives. The project is contributing to the mission of the SFS program by: (1) providing government organizations with cybersecurity professionals that possess the research, scientific, technological, analytic, and cultural competencies required to support the nation's long term security requirements; (2) providing professional development and academic mentorship to students to enhance their potential to support current and future National and Homeland Security requirements; (3) facilitating programs and protocols that enhance the opportunities for students and faculty to engage in cybersecurity education and research.

The project is promoting academic and extracurricular cybersecurity programs at Penn State and its partners, in particular historically underrepresented groups. The principle investigators are women actively involved in recruiting other women in science, and they are recruiting women to the SFS program as well. The project's curriculum development and research initiatives are addressing government priorities and strengthening existing ties to federal partners as well as creating new partnerships to support the Nation's cyber defense.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF Scholarship for Service Program  (SFS) at The Pennsylvania State University (Penn State)  focused on producing highly prepared students for the government workforce. The project was housed in the College of Information Sciences and Technology (IST), from 2011 to 2018. It has  attracted students from several disciplines including Information Sciences and Technology, Computer Science and Engineering, and International Affairs. Key outcomes include a group of 26 graduates, mostly undergraduate students.  Our SFS graduates successfully met program requirements by starting a profession in the government, with an emphasis on the federal agencies. Students were mentored by professors at Penn State and educated about cybersecurity and national security along with their potential  for the government workforce.  

Other relevant outcomes include  strengthening at Penn State of activities related to cybersecurity in undergraduate education along with tighter  relationships with several federal agencies. The SFS presence in the College of IST led to a stronger presence of  PSU  students in nation-wide capture the flag competitions (and other cybersecurity competitions) over multiple years, and more active students’ led club on cybersecurity. Finally, several sections of mentoring and professional development courses were offered throughout the years. Our SFS specific  course was developed by the PI team and has  helped several students transition to the government workforce. It is still offered currently to the new class of SFS students. Of note, the project contributed to the start of a new culture at the College of IST  that re-emphasized the role of cybersecurity in undergraduate and graduate education and its connection with the government.
